speaker: Jennifer Walsh
text: Alright everyone, thanks for joining the sprint retrospective. Let's start with what went well this sprint. Tom, want to kick us off?

speaker: Tom Bradley
text: Sure, I think the new deployment pipeline saved us tons of time. We went from 2-hour releases to 20 minutes. Really happy with that improvement.

speaker: Lisa Park
text: Agreed on the pipeline! Also, the daily standups felt much more focused this sprint. People actually stuck to the 15-minute limit.

speaker: Jennifer Walsh
text: Great points. Now, what didn't go well? I'll be honest - I felt like we had too many interruptions from urgent bug reports. It derailed our planned work.

speaker: Carlos Mendez
text: Yeah, those production issues were brutal. Three different P0 bugs in one week? That's not normal. I wonder if our testing coverage is lacking somewhere.

speaker: Tom Bradley
text: I can look into the test coverage this week. But honestly, two of those bugs were from edge cases that would be really hard to catch in testing.

speaker: Lisa Park
text: What if we implement better monitoring instead? Catch issues before they become P0s? I've been looking at some APM tools that might help.

speaker: Jennifer Walsh
text: I like that direction. Lisa, can you research APM options and present 2-3 recommendations next week? Tom, focus on test coverage analysis. Carlos, anything you want to own?

speaker: Carlos Mendez
text: I'll work on documenting our incident response process. It felt chaotic last week - we need clearer escalation paths. Should have it ready by Friday.

speaker: Jennifer Walsh
text: Excellent. So action items: Lisa on APM research, Tom on test coverage, Carlos on incident docs. All due next Friday. Thanks everyone, great retro!
